title: Win rates aren't an accurate measure of a champion's strength

I don't fucking get it. Whenever I mention that {{champion:222}}  has both an absurdly high pick and win rate for several months, I get downvoted quite heavily. Lucian after his "nerfs" and Tristana never reached the level of popularity and success that Jinx has at this moment, and those 2 champions were qq'ed about for months on end until Riot nerfed them patch after patch. Why is Jinx so special?

Because she has fans. 

Having fans makes your champion immune to legitimate balancing, that's all there is to it. I mean there's literally no other way to explain it beyond Riot balances champions as a popularity contest. 

Hell, multiple times Morello himself has very publicly stated he would've nerfed or reworked Lee Sin ages ago if RIOT wasn't scared of backlash from his fanboys. I can literally find you exact quotations of this statement.

Jinx is popular because she's essentially a non-boobilicious "powerful woman" who's pretty much the Joker. It's a character a lot of people like. As such, she's slower (or immune) to getting nerfs. Several other champions are the same way. Zed (speaking *as a Zed fan/player*, I might add), Lee Sin, Vi,  and Thresh (my go-to support pick, I might add)  just to name a few. Being popular gives a champion privileges. Arguing otherwise is outright naive, at this point, because Riot can and will continue to prove it's true as long as they're a popular game.

You can make all the arguments you want for how "balanced" your way-too-popular pick is, but that doesn't make you right. It makes you blind.
But Lee Sin got nerfed 3 times in Season 4.

Win-rate *isn't* a reliable indicator of a champion's strength... **on its own**. in combination with pick rate, ban rate, and statistics like "picked with" and "picked against", win rate paints a very full picture of a champion's strengths, weaknesses, and percieved strength in the eyes of players.

Sejuani is categorically OP since she has a very high win-rate *as well as combined pick and ban rate* (her pick rate is only low because she gets banned **75%** of all matches). if she had a 55% win rate for a whole year, but only showed up in 3% of matches, you'd know she is very strong in a select few situations. As it stands though, she is good in almost all situations right now, which is why *all* her statistics are higher than average.

In contrast, we have somebody like Heimer, who has been in the top 15 highest win rates in the game *since his rework over a year ago* Heimer is no longer OP though, he is just very good against specific champions (kitable/immobile champions with weak early games), which is reflected by his consistently much lower pick rate of between 3 and 4%, and near non existent ban rate, since he is also quite bad in certain matchups.

Lastly, we have Amumu. He has a higher pick rate than Sejuani with an almost identical win rate, but a fractional ban rate. This is because he is a very popular, relatively easy to use champion, but can be countered by somebody with the knowhow to counter jungle and set him behind, which is why his win rate declines the higher rank you look at.

To be precise, 'win rate' is just the mean. To accurately measure 'variability', ones need both mean and variance.

In short, win rate alone would indicate balance issue? Nope
Win rate is useless? Nope.

I forget which Rioter said it, but they described win rates as a symptom, and when you notice a win rate skewed in either direction, then you have to diagnose why it's skewed that way. For example, Release Zyra had something stupid like 64 or 67% win rate and had to be hot fixed because she did a crazy amount of damage. Lee Sin is another example. Lee's win rate for a very long time hovered between 45-48%, but he was picked in almost every other game across all elos.  Win rates are important to look at, but you have to give them context.

As far as Sejuani goes, I think she gives to much power for how simple she is to pick up. If Sejuani had a flow chart it would be:

**Start Here:** Are you sitting on the face of a carry? Yes = 1, No = 2
1.  Spam W.
2. Q towards them and spam W.

She can be played in a more nuanced way, but this basic pattern has enough power to get most people by. In other words, Seju's current skill ratio is too much power out, for too little skill in.

Win rates can be bad in certain cases.  The meta can be unfavorable for a champ.  The champ could have a play rate so low, that the data just isn't good, although, even galio has enough games in his respective roles to get a decent idea of where he sits in general (though maybe not at certain player experience levels).  The champ could just be bad.  In low winrate cases, it's harder to say.  If a champ is at the top though, it's because they're the best.  Champs that they inherently counter do worse, and champs that counter them are strong.  However, the outlier champ is usually the one at the top of the winrates.  

The biggest red flag though, is if the winrate is on the rise, and the play rate is as well.

If a champ has a low win rate and a high pick rate either

1) People who are bad are skewing the data due to how difficult the champ is to use effectively
2) People are *drastically* over-estimating the champion's power.  

That second one is usually due to the champion crushing things they counter really hard, or snowballing like crazy when they're ahead.  When such a champion happens to do well, opposing players often feel like there's nothing they can do about it which in turn leads to cries of OP.

If a champion has a high pick rate AND a high win rate, then it is usually safe to assume that they're significantly more powerful/reliable/flexible than their peers.

I have heard all the speculation about why win rate isn't important. However, the single most important stat in a given game is nexus killed. So why isn't win rate the single most important statistic to determine the strength of a champ. I can understand that the difference between 48% and 52% might be in insignificant, but at some point win rate must matter. 

I mean, people can speculate all they want why a champ has a high or low win rate but there is no way to know if they are right. It may make "sense" that difficult to play champs have a low win rate or FOTM champs have a low win rate b/c noobs play them, but where is anyone's evidence for those assertions? It's not like these win rates are over just a few games either. Over hundreds and thousands of games, why is it not safe to say a champ is overpowered if they have a 60% winrate? 55%?

I am not saying everyone is wrong and I do not know much about statistics as a science, but it is hard for me to understand why it is basically universally accepted that winrate is meaningless. Give me something other than wild speculation why win rate doesn't matter? And please don't say about how champs "feel" like how everyone bitches about Lee Sin. He can suck to play against but is really not OP and his winrate is low. I would like to see a study about his winrate with Lee Sin mains compared to other "mains" being played...THAT would be interesting.

Champions can be played at different levels. Consider a mirror match of Lee Sin against Lee Sin, same ELO, same set-up. One has played maybe 20 games of Lee Sin, one has played maybe 100. In this case the Lee Sin who has 100 games is probably going to win - the difference between a good Lee Sin and a bad Lee SIn is large. If the good Lee Sin is unstoppable in the vast majority of his games this suggests that Lee Sin is unbalanced at high levels of play.

If a champion has a high pick rate it suggests that more people new to the champion are playing it. This gives the win rate a negative skew - it is lower than it ought to be. Lee SIn fits this quite well.
 I chose Lee as an example because people typically whine about him. I personally think he is fine, but whatever...

In the case of Sejuani she has a high pick rate *and* a high win rate - even people new to the champion are winning more than they are losing. This suggests an imbalance.

Champions with exceedingly low pick rates are typically played by dedicated champion mains only. Win rate is positively skewed and is higher than it ought to be.
While pick rate is the easiest cause to see there is a myriad of other factors that determine win rate (including popular matchups, the meta and even player perception - lots of players saw Urgot as a "troll pick" only a month ago and so didn't bother in games with him).

Hope this helps!

By your own admission, you're not good with statistics: The first step is to accept that pick rate skews win rate. That's just common sense.

Statistically, the harder the champion is, the less likely players are using them to their max potential. As such, the more players pick them, the higher the discrepancy in skill between users of the champion, and as such the amount of players who *cannot* use them to their max potential exceedingly outweighs the number of players who *can*. 

This is why Qetzels Lee Sin example is an accurate one: He was, until Cinderhulk, literally the most played jungler by a near-30% pick rate margin (oftentimes having a 35+% pick rate while the 2nd most picked jungler had a 7-10% pick rate). Lee Sin isn't nearly as hard as his fanboys pretend, but he's still a mechanically difficult champion compared to most. As such, his win rate would've been skewed negatively by quite a bit. Lee Sin mains who were talented at the champion and had mastered him were likely winning *way* more than 50% of their games, while everyone who was either bad at the champion or new to the champion would have lower (sometimes *way* lower) than 50% win rates. The latter group, logically, when he has a 35% pick rate, would *vastly* outweigh the former, resulting in a negatively skewed win rate that is inaccurately representing the champion's balance state by a potentially large amount.

Thus, win rate is a bad indicator of balance, *especially* when considered in a vacuum (which, usually, is the *only* way "win rate defenders" or champion fanboys are willing to look at win rates).

Win rates aren't an accurate measure of a champion's strength, but they are an indicator to be taken into account with other factors.

What ends up giving champions high winrates are:

1. A combination of easy to use and high impact
2. Synergy with other champions who are easy to use and high impact
3. Synergy with current items and
4. How buffed/nerfed they are in comparison to other champions

This is why Sejuani is strong, because she's a combination of all four of these. She's extremely easy to use, her CC, damage, mobility and ability to soak up enemy damage makes her high impact, she synergizes with other strong picks in the meta, the strong items in the game work well on her, and she got some buff love ( and the current nerfs still haven't brought her in line yet ).
